Award.AwardTitle: RCN-UBE Incubator: Development of a Build-a-Genome Network to Teach Synthetic Biology at Diverse Undergraduate Institutions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Build-a-Genome course at Johns Hopkins University is an example of an approach to infuse authentic, interdisciplinary research experiences into the curriculum. The PI team members of this RCN-UBE network all have experience with the Build-a-Genome course and now plan to launch an undergraduate Build-a-Genome course at their own institutions and help other faculty to do the same by joining this new network. Build-a-Genome is an intensive laboratory course in which undergraduates participate in the Synthetic Yeast Project, a large-scale effort to construct the world's first synthetic eukaryotic genome. Along the way, students gain a comprehensive introduction to synthetic biology, learn basic molecular biology techniques and make important contributions to a cutting-edge research project.

Intellectual Merit: This RCN-UBE network plans to organize a national workshop at Loyola University in Maryland to introduce participants to the Build-a-Genome course, teach gene synthesis methods, and bring together individuals to develop plans for implementing similar courses at their home institutions. The network leaders will then host a series of smaller regional Build-a-Genome/gene synthesis workshops at North Carolina A&T State University and Hartwick College, targeting faculty from regional colleges to promote synthetic biology, to make connections among local institutions, and to disseminate materials developed at the national workshop.

Broader Impacts: The proposed network includes faculty from a range of institutional types (large research university, comprehensive university, and liberal arts college) and includes an HBCU and will expand to include a similar diversity of institutions. Build-a-Genome provides a truly unique, hands-on learning experience for undergraduates. Students take ownership of their projects, make important contributions to an ongoing research effort,and learn gene synthesis and molecular biology techniques while being introduced to the interdisciplinary field of synthetic biology.

This project is funded jointly by the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Directorate of Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education in support of efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Education: A Call to Action http://visionandchange.org/finalreport/

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to form a research network that will facilitate the adaptation and implementation of the Build-A-Genome (BAG) undergraduate synthetic biology research course at diverse institutions. To this end, we have organized one national BAG workshop at Loyola University Maryland and two regional BAG workshops, one at Hartwick College and another at North Carolina A&T State University. One of the primary goals of our workshops has been to introduce faculty members interested in starting the BAG synthetic biology course to the tools that they will need to most effectively implement the course at their home institutions. Therefore, during the workshops, in addition to interactive presentations about synthetic biology, course dynamics and the larger synthetic yeast (Sc2.0) project, the participants were given the opportunity to gain hands-on experience with the gene synthesis protocols used in the course (e.g., each participant synthesized their own DNA building block). This allowed participants to experience the workflow currently utilized in the course. Both the lab experience and the presentations stimulated very fruitful discussions about strategies for (and potential barriers to) implementation of the BAG course at their home institutions. Currently, the National Build-A-Genome Network includes 24 faculty members who are engaged in undergraduate education at a diverse collection of institutional settings, including high research institutions, U.S. service academies, comprehensive universities, liberal arts colleges, community colleges and even a STEM-intensive high school.

The formation of the National Build-A-Genome Network has enabled the development and dissemination of pedagogical materials (e.g., a BAG lab instruction manual and assessment tools for the course) that will facilitate adaptation and implementation of BAG and related synthetic biology curricula at diverse institutional settings. The BAG model, which promotes the integration of authentic, inquiry-driven research experiences in the context of a synthetic biology course, also provides undergraduate students with the unique opportunity to participate in cutting-edge research as part of the Synthetic Yeast Project (Sc2.0), which itself is a major milestone in the field of biology. Importantly, because synthetic biology is an emerging field that integrates multiple scientific disciplines, including biology, mathematics, chemistry, and computer science for assembling novel biological devices (or even entire genomes) with useful properties, students are able to experience the excitement of scientific discovery in a multidisciplinary context. Indeed, by working at the interface of these disciplines, students in the BAG course gain a deeper understanding of the interrelationship between these disciplines as well as an appreciation for the collaborative nature of science. Therefore, the formation of a BAG network that facilitates the development and dissemination of pedagogical materials to expand the BAG curriculum to diverse institutions stands to have a great impact not only on biology students, but also on a variety of STEM disciplines.
